Deftux
Feature Stub

Recent:


Day 60: Parallels App Integration

What it is: Parallels is a Windows virtualization application for Macs. (It lets you run a Windows machine on your Mac, inception style.) The applications that Parallels virtualizes run on your dock alongside your regular applications.

Why it’s good: Your users don’t care a single iota about your data model. Let me rephrase that, unless they’re required to interact with your data model, the users shouldn’t have to care about it.

Someone at Parallels asked the question “What is it you’re trying to do?” The answer is usually “I want to run a Windows application on my Mac.” Parallels is helping you bridge that gap by removing the first step—launching the virtualized machine. Your average user doesn’t want to think about the prerequisites for getting to their task. They don’t want to have to process: “I need to launch this other program before I can launch the program I want inside of it.”

Breaking down the technological barriers and allowing the user’s tasks to surface is an essential goal of UX design. Parallels removes the most confusing step from a complex task so the user only needs to think about their goal.


Day 59: Primer’s Content

What it is: Primer is a series of bite sized marketing lessons developed by Google. The content is presented as a stack of cards that are flipped through.

Why it’s good: We have a tendency to design for mobile as if it’s a laptop with an oddly-sized screen. It may just be symptomatic of how new mobile tech is, but it doesn’t fit how users approach their devices. We use mobile phones in short bursts, in busy environments, in the times between events. Designing for linear consumption just doesn’t make sense.

Primer clearly designs their content for mobile consumption. Content is broken up into tiny chunks, like notecards for a speech that you can flip through. Each card has a pin on it, letting you pull out important nuggets to remember later. Pinned cards appear in their own section of the app, letting you see highlights from across multiple lessons. The lessons themselves are only a few minutes long, and each includes a progress bar, a few quizzes, and a few sections of cards.

As we begin adopting new mediums, which come with new methods of interaction and new abilities, it’s lazy to assume we can keep creating and using content in the same way. Primer’s content is written to be consumed in short bursts, and its design complements that. This exemplifies how we should think about the context in which users will interact with content on specific devices.


Day 58: Google Fi’s Gift

What it is: Google Fi sent me a package a few weeks after I signed up for their service. It thanked me for being an early customer, and included a set of headphones, an external battery, and a case for my phone.

Why it’s good: Giving a gift always goes over well. What you give—and how you give it—matter a lot, though. Google Fi hit it out of the park here.

First, they didn’t tell me to expect anything. I didn’t receive a shipping notice; it just appeared on my doorstep on Monday. I was genuinely surprised. The language throughout the box is friendly and direct: “Hello again” as a greeting, “Thanks for being here from the beginning” as an explanation on the bottom of the lid, and cute labels on each item. The headphones are an odd design that allow you to plug in a secondary pair, and say “Turn airdrum solos into airdrum duets.” The battery pack and case say “100% all natural juice for your phone” and “Even phones need hugs.”


Day 57: Bucknell’s IA

What it is: When Bucknell redesigned their site last year with the aid of the incomparable Fastspot, they went for a radical IA that allows multiple methods of navigation through the site content.

Why it’s good: I am guilty of harping at people for wanting to do new things for the hell of it. Creating different things is great and fun, but you end up having to help the user along much more. Most people don’t want to do that second step.

This IA condenses everything into a single massive, searchable directory. Complimenting this directory is a persona based navigation that uses natural language, helping you wayfind to something more useful if you don’t know what you’re looking for. A “Recent Pages” section functions as a support element, letting you find things that are recent and giving you a soft bookmark for any relevant pages.

This is why it’s so hard to copy designs too - they live in an ecosystem. Without the persona navigation, the directory wouldn’t serve the needs of users who aren’t sure of their goals yet. Without powerful search tools, the everything directory is too hard to navigate. The persona nav is too limited in scope to handle everyone’s needs. With a traditional hierarchical model, the history feature turns into more noise than content. Together though, these tools turn into a suite of navigation that feels different and so much smoother than navigating departments and majors to get simple information.


Day 56: Tasty’s Walkthroughs

What it is: Tasty (and Buzzfeed cooking) use this style of video where it is filmed from overheard with ingredient overlays and ramping between important steps in the cooking process.

Why it’s good: These videos are largely designed to be shared through social media platforms, and it shows in the way that they are filmed. They are essentially unbranded (They have no celebrity associated with them), and are very simply focused on the steps required and the end result.

I particularly enjoy that the overhead camera shows you the entire process - but it also shows you the specific points that need attention. You get an idea on how much time it takes and how difficult it is because there are no cuts, just speed changes. You see how the ingredients change over time and what it needs to look like - but without any cruft or explanations.

Another nice touch is answering a question before it’s asked. This particular recipe calls for a spice mix. After explaining the amount needed, the video cuts itself in half and shows you how to build the mix yourself (just in case you aren’t the type to have a jar of Cajun Spices sitting about.) The visualization feels paranthetical, it unpacks an item and shows you how it’s made without losing context in the greater recipe.
